content.text: Explain what is meant by a geostationary orbit
A satellite of mass \(m\) is in a circular orbit about a planet
The mass \(M\) of the planet may be considered to be concentrated at its centre
Show that the radius \(R\) of the orbit of the satellite is given by the expression
where \(T\) is the period of the orbit of the satellite and \(G\) is the gravitational constant. Explain your working
The Earth has mass \(6.0 \times 10^{24} \text{kg}\). Use the expression given in **(b)** to determine the radius of the geostationary orbit about the Earth
Calculate
1. the amount of gas, in mol, in the cylinder,
amount =   .........  mol
2. the rise in temperature of the gas
temperature rise =   .........  K
Use your answer in **(i)** **part 2** to show that the final pressure of the gas in the cylinder is \(2.95 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\)
The volume of an ideal gas in a cylinder is \(1.80 \times 10^{-3} \text{m}^3\) at a pressure of \(2.60 \times 10^5 \text{Pa}\) and a temperature of \(297 \text{K}\), as illustrated in Fig. 2.1
The thermal energy required to raise the temperature by \(1.00 \text{K}\) of \(1.00 \text{mol}\) of the gas at constant volume is \(12.5 \text{J}\)
The gas is heated at constant volume such that the internal energy of the gas increases by \(95.0 \text{J}\)
The gas is now allowed to expand. No thermal energy enters or leaves the gas
The gas does 120J of work when expanding against the external pressure
State and explain whether the final temperature of the gas is above or below 297K
calculate the angular frequency \(\omega\),
determine numerical equations for the variation with time \(t\) of
1. the displacement \(\mathbf{x}\) in cm,
2. the speed \(\nu\) in \(\text{m s}^{-1}\)
The mass is released at time \(t = 0\)
For the oscillations of the mass,
Calculate the total energy of oscillation of the mass
For
Examiner's
Use
energy =   .........  J
A mass of \(78\mathrm{g}\) is suspended from a fixed point by means of a spring, as illustrated in Fig. 3.1
The stationary mass is pulled vertically downwards through a distance of \(2.1 \text{cm}\) and then released
The mass is observed to perform simple harmonic motion with a period of \(0.69 \text{s}\)
State a formula, in terms of \(R\) and \(q\), for the potential \(V\) on the surface of the sphere
Define capacitance and hence show that the capacitance \(C\) of the sphere is given by the expression
An insulated metal sphere of radius \(R\) is situated in a vacuum. The charge \(q\) on the sphere may be considered to be a point charge at the centre of the sphere
Use the expression in (a)(ii) to calculate the capacitance, in picofarad, of the sphere
capacitance =   .........  pF
The sphere is charged to a potential of \(9.0 \times 10^{5} \text{V}\)
A spark occurs, partially discharging the sphere so that its potential is reduced to \(3.6 \times 10^{5} \text{V}\)
Determine the energy of the spark
An isolated metal sphere has radius \(45 \text{cm}\)
Fig. 5.1
The wires pass through a horizontal card PQRS
The current in wire X is 6.3 A in the upward direction. Initially, there is no current in wire Y
On Fig. 5.1, sketch, in the plane PQRS, the magnetic flux pattern due to the current in wire X. Show at least four flux lines
The magnetic flux density \(B\) at a distance \(x\) from a long straight current-carrying wire is given by the expression
where \(I\) is the current in the wire and \(\mu_0\) is the permeability of free space
Calculate the magnetic flux density at wire Y due to the current in wire X
flux density =   .........  T
A current of 9.3A is now switched on in wire Y. Use your answer in **(ii)** to calculate the force per unit length on wire Y
Define the _tesla_
Two long straight vertical wires X and Y are separated by a distance of 4.5 cm, as illustrated in Fig  .........  5.1
The currents in the two wires in **(b)**(iii) are not equal
Explain whether the force per unit length on the two wires will be the same, or different
State Faraday's law of electromagnetic induction
On Fig. 6.1, mark with the letter P the positive output from the rectifier
Calculate the ratio
number of turns on primary coil
number of turns on secondary coil`
The output of an ideal transformer is connected to a bridge rectifier, as shown in Fig. 6.1
The input to the transformer is \(240\mathrm{V r.m.s.}\) and the maximum potential difference across the load resistor is \(9.0\mathrm{V}\)
Explain what is meant by smoothing
On Fig. 6.2, draw the variation with time \(t\) of the smoothed output potential difference
The variation with time \(t\) of the potential difference \(V\) across the load resistor in **(b)** is shown in Fig. 6.2
A capacitor is now connected in parallel with the load resistor to produce some smoothing
The emission spectrum of atomic hydrogen consists of a number of discrete wavelengths. Explain how this observation leads to an understanding that there are discrete electron energy levels in atoms
The longest wavelength produced as a result of electron transitions between two of the energy levels shown in Fig. 7.1 is \(4.0 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}\)
On Fig. 7.1,
1. draw, and mark with the letter L, the transition giving rise to the wavelength of \(4.0 \times 10^{- 6} \text{m}\),
2. draw, and mark with the letter S, the transition giving rise to the shortest wavelength
Calculate the wavelength for the transition you have shown in (i) part 2
wavelength =   .........  m
Some electron energy levels in atomic hydrogen are illustrated in Fig. 7.1
Photon energies in the visible spectrum vary between approximately \(3.66 \text{eV}\) and \(1.83 \text{eV}\)
Determine the energies, in eV, of photons in the visible spectrum that are produced by transitions between the energy levels shown in Fig. 7.1
photon energies   .........  eV
Explain why the mass of an \(\alpha\) -particle is less than the total mass of two individual protons and two individual neutrons
Calculate the mass change, in u, associated with this reaction
mass change =   .........  \(u\)
Calculate the energy, in J, associated with the mass change in (i)
energy =   .........  J
Suggest and explain why, for this reaction to occur, the helium-4 nucleus must have a minimum speed
An equation for one possible nuclear reaction is
Data for the masses of the nuclei are given in Fig. 8.1
Use Fig. 9.1 to determine the range of volume over which the volume has a linear relationship to the voltmeter reading
from   .........  litres to   .........  litres
when the tank is nearly full, the voltmeter readings give the impression that fuel consumption is low,
when the voltmeter first indicates that the tank is nearly empty, there is more fuel remaining than is expected
Suggest why, comparing values from Fig. 9.1,
Answer all the questions in the spaces provided

The volume of fuel in the fuel tank of a car is monitored using a sensing device. The device gives a voltage output that is measured using a voltmeter. The variation of voltmeter reading with the volume of fuel in the tank is shown in Fig. 9.1
Fig. 9.1
By reference to ultrasound waves, state what is meant by acoustic impedance
An ultrasound wave is incident on the boundary between two media. The acoustic impedances of the two media are \(Z_{1}\) and \(Z_{2}\), as illustrated in Fig. 10.1
Explain the importance of the difference between \(Z_{1}\) and \(Z_{2}\) for the transmission of ultrasound across the boundary
Ultrasound frequencies as high as \(10\mathrm{MHz}\) are used in medical diagnosis
State and explain one advantage of the use of high-frequency ultrasound compared with lower-frequency ultrasound
Explain how the hardness of an X-ray beam is controlled by the accelerating voltage in the X-ray tube
State
1. what is meant by attenuation,
2. why the expression applies only to a parallel beam
The linear attenuation coefficients for X-rays in bone and in soft tissue are \(2.9 \text{cm}^{-1}\) and \(0.95 \text{cm}^{-1}\) respectively
Calculate, for a parallel X-ray beam, the ratio
fraction \(\frac{I}{I_0}\) of intensity transmitted through soft tissue of thickness \(6.0 \text{cm}\)
The attenuation of a parallel beam of X-ray radiation is given by the expression
where \(\mu\) is the linear attenuation (absorption) coefficient and \(x\) is the thickness of the material through which the beam passes
State the purpose of the parallel-to-serial converter
The ADC (analogue-to-digital converter) samples the analogue signal at a frequency of \(5.0\mathrm{kHz}\)
Each sample from the ADC is a four-bit digital number where the smallest bit represents \(1.0\mathrm{mV}\)
The first sample is taken at time zero
Use Fig. 12.2 to determine the four-bit digital number produced by the ADC at times
0.8 ms
Part of the signal from the microphone is shown in Fig. 12.2
The digital signal is transmitted and then converted to an analogue form by the DAC (digital-to-analogue converter)
Using data from Fig. 12.2, draw, on the axes of Fig. 12.3, the output level of the transmitted analogue signal for time zero to time \(1.2\mathrm{ms}\)
output
level
State and explain the effect on the transmitted analogue waveform of increasing, for the ADC and the DAC, both the sampling frequency and the number of bits in each sample
The digital transmission of speech may be represented by the block diagram of Fig. 12.1
